channel.title: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds
channel.description: New PCs could start in just seconds, thanks to an update to one of the oldest parts of desktop computers. The upgrade will spell the end for the 25-year-old PC start-up software known as Bios that initialises a machine so its operating system can get going. The code was not intended to live nearly this long, and adapting it to modern PCs is one reason they take as long as they do to warm up. Bios' replacement, known as UEFI, will predominate in new PCs by 2011.

item.title: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

@Kane, as the above posts pointed out, Apple used to make everything in their machines, but now they use the exact same parts as any other PC manufacturer (like Dell for example). They use Intel CPUs, Nvidia GPUs, and basically everything else is the same. You can get just as much support by calling dell about your dell or apple about your apple I’m sure. I wouldn’t really know about that though, I build my own computers and fix my own problems.

Read full topic
item.source: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds

item.title: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“bootnecklad, post:39, topic:362434”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=458720.msg3371788#msg3371788 date=1287285915]

Mac > PC.
I would never switch back.

Uh, sorry to burst your bubble, but Macs ARE PCs now.

And Kubuntu on this laptop takes somewhere around 10 seconds to boot up.

slow.

Windows 7 boots in under 6 for me

Windows 7 on this same laptop probably takes about 15 seconds.

OSX > Windows 7.

Bubble unburst.

OSX probably is better than Windows 7, I’ve never said otherwise. I don’t think it’s worth the cost though, especially when Linux is free and better than both of them.

But new Macs are the same as PCs (hardware-wise), nothing changes that fact.

I see your point, but although hardware is important, It’s the way It’s used.
Apple make everything within their machines - they make them work in the most power efficient and fastest way with what they’ve got (Hardware wise). Having everything within an Apple product made by Apple also guarantees that you only need to go into an Apple store to get it all fixed, instead of calling a bunch of indian places/having foreign shit in a computer that you can’t find to replace and so on.

Their machines are the most environmentally friendly, as well. I’ve never seen a laptop use battery life better than a MacBook.

But It’s all a difference of opinion and most importantly, personal preference.
Yes, they’re expensive, but you pay for efficiency, durability and reliability. - My opinion.

[/quote]

I don’t think they make everything anything inside there machines…[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds

item.title: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Kane., post:17, topic:362434”]My MacBook Pro starts up in about 15 seconds, just timed it.
I’ve had it for ages, still works like It’s new.

Mac > PC.
I would never switch back.[/quote]

Xp boots in 8 seconds from a ssd for me(bios taking 9 seconds so 17 seconds all together, I broke a connection so it takes 2-3 seconds to find all the peripherals), stock fedora 11 boots in 10 seconds and most linux distros can get <8 seconds easily on any regular harddrive.

Read full topic

item.title: Change to 'Bios' will make for PCs that boot in seconds
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:362434”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=458720.msg3360742#msg3360742 date=1286335809]
Mac > PC.
I would never switch back.
[/quote]

Uh, sorry to burst your bubble, but Macs ARE PCs now.[/quote]
Just the software people run is different!

What was the whole speed thing about?

Moparisthebest:

It’s not an entirely fair comparison to make, OSX doesn’t have to worry about probing for hardware and loading particular drivers like windows or linux. This is because OSX only runs on Apple branded computers made by Apple, so it knows exactly what hardware it will run on and what drivers to load without any probing around.

So Microsoft need to stop supporting loads of things? Wasn’t that the intention, get a PC running on every desktop with MS software on it? Couldn’t do that if you only supported a limited range of hardware!

Is there anyway to have a fast system that deals with a range of hardware!!!111’’@@@@@111!!!@’

Read full topic
